definitions.definition: The chemical element ( symbol C ) with an atomic number of 6. It can be found in pure form for example as graphite , a black , shiny and very soft material, or diamond , a colourless , transparent , crystalline solid and the hardest known material.
examples: All life as we know it has carbon as the backbone of many of its molecules; carbon ’s tetravalence gives it special importance in biochemical molecular bonds.

definitions.definition: An atom of this element, in reference to a molecule containing it.
examples: A methane molecule is made up of a single carbon with four hydrogens.
Please provide me with a carbon of your form.
Press firmly: you are making a carbon .

definitions.definition: A fossil fuel that is made of impure carbon such as coal or charcoal .

examples: Every morning she cleaned the carbon from the lamp chimneys.

subdefinitions.definition: Especially, hardened soot as a caked-on deposit .
examples: When you overhaul an engine, you need to remove the carbon from around the valve seats. The carbon buildup can be extensive.

definitions.definition: A carbon rod or pencil used in an arc lamp .
A plate or piece of carbon used as one of the elements of a voltaic battery .

main_definition: ( uncountable ) The chemical element ( symbol C ) with an atomic number of 6. It can be found in pure form for example as graphite , a black , shiny and very soft material, or diamond , a colourless , transparent , crystalline solid and the hardest known material.
secondary_definitions: ( countable ) An atom of this element, in reference to a molecule containing it.
( countable , informal ) A sheet of carbon paper .
A fossil fuel that is made of impure carbon such as coal or charcoal .
( ecology , climate change , uncountable ) Ellipsis of carbon dioxide .
A carbon rod or pencil used in an arc lamp .
A plate or piece of carbon used as one of the elements of a voltaic battery .
( informal ) Ellipsis of carbon fiber (reinforced polymer) .
